It‚Äôs understandable to want to do more. But we must understand what is at stake. The risks of two nuclear powers going to war are dramatically increased by a no-fly zone. This is unimaginable, and would risk many more civilian casualties than a no-fly zone would save.
And if Russia retaliated, as they certainly would, our Article 5 obligation would be triggered ‚Äì and the U.S. would be at war with Russia.
This would mean the U.S. declaring war on Russia. The same goes for if a NATO ally were to enforce the no-fly zone. They too might have to shoot down Russian jets.

A no-fly zone is enforced, not declared. It requires our fighter jets to go directly against Russian fighter jets, to get them to stay out of a certain airspace. If the U.S. were to do this, our fighter jets would potentially have to shoot down Russian jets.

The U.S. & NATO are united in our support for Ukraine. It's the right thing to do in the face of Russian aggression ‚Äîbut we need to be smart about how we do that.

A no-fly zone seems simple, even the bare minimum to save lives. But let‚Äôs talk through what this actually means. üßµ

¬†
We must allocate funds to support the resettlement of refugees and provide other forms of assistance to the victims of Putin's war.

These were the right call and will drive up the cost of this war for Putin.

I also believe we should continue to look for additional means to respond, including terminating Russia‚Äôs ability to use SWIFT.

We should also continue providing defensive military support to Ukraine.

Before the war, the admin crafted a massive sanctions package to respond to an invasion.

Those sanctions have been issued, and will cause significant pain to the Russian economy. They cut off banks from the global finance system, target oligarchs, and block high-tech exports.

Over the next days, I will be closely watching Kyiv.

From Putin's public statements, I believe he intends to remove Ukraine's leadership to install pro-Russian puppets.

Russian forces are already encircling Kyiv and other major cities. Civilian casualties could be very high.

Ukraine‚Äôs President Zelenskyy has demonstrated incredible bravery, leading his nation under assault.

The Ukrainian military and ordinary citizens are doing the same and our prayers - and unrelenting support - are with them as they defend their nation against Russian invaders.

First, while we are still in the early days, I believe Putin likely underestimated the Ukrainian will to fight.

Russia has an advantage in firepower and numbers, but the Ukrainians are fighting for their freedom and on their own soil. 

They will not give up without a struggle.
